Thus \[(\cos (-2 \pi)+i \sin (-2 \pi))\cdot (\cos (-\frac{4 \pi}{15})+i \sin (-\frac{4 \pi}{15}))\cdots (\cos (\frac{16 \pi}{15})+i \sin (\frac{16 \pi}{15}))=e^{-2 i \pi }\cdot e^{-\frac{4 i \pi }{15}}\cdots e^{\frac{16 i \pi }{15}}=e^{(-2+\frac{4}{15}-\frac{8}{15}+\cdots +\frac{16}{15})i }.\]This simplifies using geometric series summation as follows:\begin{align*}&e^{(-2+\frac{4}{15}-\frac{8}{15}+\cdots +\frac{16}{15})i

ost_step.4: Our result now reduces to simply $$-i \sin {\small{\frac{224}{15}}}\approx -0.999.$$

Condition 1:  Let us simplify \[\cos \left( \frac{2 \pi}{15} \right) \cos \left (\frac {4 \pi}{15} \right) \cos \left( \frac{8 \pi}{15} \right) \cos \left( \frac {16 \pi}{15} \right).\ \] Note that all four angles add up to $6 \pi / 5$: \[ \frac{2 \pi}{15} +\frac{4 \pi }{15} +\frac{8 \pi}{15}+ \frac{16 \pi}{15}=6 \pi / 5 .\] Thus we may let $w=\operatorname{cis}(\theta)$ satisfy $$ w ^4+\bar w ^4=-2.$$ Using Vieta’s formulas and then DeMoivre’s theorem again,\begin{align*} & w^{20}-(-w^{20}) &= (-2)^5 \\ w^{20}+w^{-20} &=32 \\f(w)+f(w^{-1})&=32.\end{align*} We know how much larger than $-2$ our new function must get—namely, $(2)^{20}$. To find exactly when they take those same values, consider them modulo unity, or complex conjugates acting on themselves under multiplication ($z z^*$). They attain their maxiumum absolute magnitudes simultaneously after rotating about halfway around the circle, since if $|z|=r$ , $|\bar z |= r $. Then because angle addition corresponds multiplicatively ($\zeta_k \cdot \zeta_m =\zeta_{km}, k, m \in \mathbf I$), both functions reach the maximimum magnitude at the midpoint of their respective periods. \[

\]
\[
\cos \left(\frac{16\pi}{15}\right) = \text{Re}(e^{-\frac{7\pi i}{15}})
\]

direct_answer.text:
It seems your message was cut off before it could finish explaining another approach based on transforming into even powers of sines or other relevant operations. However, focusing back on what you were asking initially - finding expressions equivalent to $(\cos x)'$, we start by recalling basic derivatives rules combined with trigonometric differentiation properties:

For $\cos(ax)$, according to the chain rule applied during calculus derivation, differentiate first considering 'a' constant outside of the cosine function and subsequently applying standard derivative results yields:
$(d/dx)[\cos ax] = -\sin(ax) \times d/dx(ax) = -a\sin(ax)$  
Now replacing '$a$' with '-1', giving rise to the relationship:
$(d/dx)[-\cos x]= -(-\sin x) = \sin x$   
As expected! By following simple application of fundamental calculus concepts concerning trigonometric functions one can arrive right away at the desired conclusion confirming the initial claim made in Example
